sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: According to our yesterday's agreement, Socrates, we have come ourselves, as we were bound to do, and we bring also this man with us; he is a stranger from Elea, one of the followers of Parmenides and Zeno, and a real philosopher.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Are you not unwittingly bringing, as Homer says, some god, and no mere stranger, Theodorus? He says that the gods, and especially the god of strangers, enter into companionship with men who have a share of due reverenceA modified quotation from Hom. Od. 9.271; Hom. Od. 17.485-7 and that they behold the deeds, both violent and righteous,Cf. Od. 17.485-7 of mankind. So perhaps this companion of yours may be one of the higher powers, who comes to watch over and refute us because we are worthless in argument—a kind of god of refutation.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: No, Socrates, that is not the stranger's character; he is more reasonable than those who devote themselves to disputation. And though I do not think he is a god at all, I certainly do think he is divine, for I give that epithet to all philosophers.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: And rightly, my friend. However, I fancy it is not much easier, if I may say so, to recognize this class, than that of the gods. For these men—I mean those who are not feignedly but really philosophers—appear disguised in all sorts of shapes,Cf. Hom. Od. 17.485-7. thanks to the ignorance of the rest of mankind, and “visit the cities,”Hom. Od. 17.485-7 beholding from above the life of those below, and they seem to some to be of no worth and to others to be worth everything. And sometimes they appear disguised as statesmen and sometimes as sophists, and sometimes they may give some people the impression that they are altogether mad. But I should like to ask our stranger here, if agreeable to him, what people in his country thought about these matters, and what names they used.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: What matters do you mean?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Sophist, statesman, philosopher.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: What particular difficulty and what kind of difficulty in regard to them is it about which you had in mind to ask?

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: It is this: Did they consider all these one, or two, or, as there are three names, did they divide them into three classes and ascribe to each a class, corresponding to a single name?

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: I think he has no objection to talking about them. What do you say, stranger?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Just what you did, Theodorus; for I have no objection, and it is not difficult to say that they considered them three. But it is no small or easy task to define clearly the nature of each.

sp.speaker: Theodorus
sp.p: The fact is, Socrates, that by chance you have hit upon a question very like what we happened to be asking him before we came here; and he made excuses to us then, as he does now to you; though he admits that he has heard it thoroughly discussed and remembers what he heard.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: In that case, stranger, do not refuse us the first favor we have asked; but just tell us this: Do you generally prefer to expound in a long uninterrupted speech of your own whatever you wish to explain to anyone, or do you prefer the method of questions? I was present once when Parmenides employed the latter method and carried on a splendid discussion. I was a young man then, and he was very old.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The method of dialogue, Socrates, is easier with an interlocutor who is tractable and gives no trouble; but otherwise I prefer the continuous speech by one person.

sp.speaker: Socrates
sp.p: Well, you may choose whomever you please of those present; they will all respond pleasantly to you; but if you take my advice you will choose one of the young fellows, Theaetetus here, or any of the others who suits you.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Socrates, this is the first time I have come among you, and I am somewhat ashamed, instead of carrying on the discussion by merely giving brief replies to your questions, to deliver an extended, long drawn out speech, either as an address of my own or in reply to another, as if I were giving an exhibition; but I must, for really the present subject is not what one might expect from the form of the question, but is a matter for very long speech. On the other hand it seems unfriendly and discourteous to refuse a favor to you and these gentlemen, especially when you have spoken as you did. As for Theaetetus I accept him most willingly as interlocutor in view of my previous conversation with him and of your present recommendation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But, stranger, by taking this course and following Socrates's suggestion will you please the others too?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I am afraid there is nothing more to be said about that, Theaetetus; but from now on, my talk will, I fancy, be addressed to you. And if you get tired and are bored by the length of the talk, do not blame me, but these friends of yours.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Oh, no, I do not think I shall get tired of it so easily, but if such a thing does happen, we will call in this Socrates, the namesake of the other Socrates; he is of my own age and my companion in the gymnasium, and is in the habit of working with me in almost everything.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Very well; you will follow your own devices about that as the discussion proceeds; but now you and I must investigate in common, beginning first, as it seems to me, with the sophist, and must search out and make plain by argument what he is. For as yet you and I have nothing in common about him but the name; but as to the thing to which we give the name, we may perhaps each have a conception of it in our own minds; however, we ought always in every instance to come to agreement about the thing itself by argument rather than about the mere name without argument. But the tribe which we now intend to search for, the sophist, is not the easiest thing in the world to catch and define, and everyone has agreed long ago that if investigations of great matters are to be properly worked out we ought to practice them on small and easier matters before attacking the very greatest. So now, Theaetetus, this is my advice to ourselves, since we think the family of sophists is troublesome and hard to catch, that we first practise the method of hunting in something easier, unless you perhaps have some simpler way to suggest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I have not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we take some lesser thing and try to use it as a pattern for the greater?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, what example can we set before us which is well known and small, but no less capable of definition than any of the greater things? Say an angler; is he not known to all and unworthy of any great interest?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But I hope he offers us a method and is capable of a definition not unsuitable to our purpose.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That would be good.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come now; let us begin with him in this way: Tell me, shall we say that he is a man with an art, or one without an art, but having some other power?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not one without an art.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But of all arts there are, speaking generally, two kinds?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Agriculture and all kinds of care of any living beings, and that which has to do with things which are put together or molded (utensils we call them), and the art of imitation—all these might properly be called by one name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so, and what is the name?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When anyone brings into being something which did not previously exist, we say that he who brings it into being produces it and that which is brought into being is produced.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now all the arts which we have just mentioned direct their energy to production.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, call these collectively the productive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And after this comes the whole class of learning and that of acquiring knowledge, and money making, and fighting, and hunting. None of these is creative, but they are all engaged in coercing, by deeds or words, things which already exist and have been produced, or in preventing others from coercing them; therefore all these divisions together might very properly be called acquisitive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that would be proper.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since acquisitive and productive art comprise all the arts, in which, Theaetetus, shall we place the art of angling?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In acquisitive art, clearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And are there not two classes of acquisitive art—one the class of exchange between voluntary agents by means of gifts and wages and purchases, and the other, which comprises all the rest of acquisitive art, and, since it coerces either by word or deed, might be called coercive?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It appears so, at any rate, from what you have said.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, shall we not divide coercive art into two parts?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By calling all the open part of it fighting and all the secret part hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But it would be unreasonable not to divide hunting into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Say how it can be done.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By dividing it into the hunting of the lifeless and of the living.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly, if both exist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of course they exist. And we must pass over the hunting of lifeless things, which has no name, with the exception of some kinds of diving and the like, which are of little importance; but the hunting of living things we will call animal-hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And two classes of animal-hunting might properly be made, one (and this is divided under many classes and names) the hunting of creatures that go on their feet, land-animal hunting, and the other that of swimming creatures, to be called, as a whole, water-animal hunting?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And of swimming creatures we see that one tribe is winged and the other is in the water?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the hunting of winged creatures is called, as a whole, fowling.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the hunting of water creatures goes by the general name of fishing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And might I not divide this kind of hunting into two principal divisions?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What divisions?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The one carries on the hunt by means of enclosures merely, the other by a blow.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean, and how do you distinguish the two?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: As regards the first, because whatever surrounds anything and encloses it so as to constrain it is properly called an enclosure.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: May not, then, wicker baskets and seines and snares and nets and the like be called enclosures?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Assuredly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we will call this division hunting by enclosures, or something of that sort.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the other, which is done with a blow, by means of hooks and three pronged spears, we must now—to name it with a single word— call striking; or could a better name be found, Theaetetus?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Never mind the name; that will do well enough.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the kind of striking which takes place at night by the light of a fire is, I suppose, called by the hunters themselves fire-hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And that which belongs to the daytime is, as a whole, barb-hunting, since the spears, as well as the hooks, are tipped with barbs.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is so called.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then of striking which belongs to barb-hunting, that part which proceeds downward from above, is called, because tridents are chiefly used in it, tridentry, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, some people, at any rate, call it so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then there still remains, I may say, only one further kind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The kind that is characterized by the opposite sort of blow, which is practised with a hook and strikes, not any chance part of the body of the fishes, as tridents do, but only the head and mouth of the fish caught, and proceeds from below upwards, being pulled up by twigs and rods. By what name, Theaetetus, shall we say this ought to be called?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think our search is now ended and we have found the very thing we set before us a while ago as necessary to find.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now, then, you and I are not only agreed about the name of angling, but we have acquired also a satisfactory definition of the thing itself. For of art as a whole, half was acquisitive, and of the acquisitive, half was coercive, and of the coercive, half was hunting, and of hunting, half was animal hunting, and of animal hunting, half was water hunting, and, taken as a whole, of water hunting the lower part was fishing, and of fishing, half was striking, and of striking, half was barb-hunting, and of this the part in which the blow is pulled from below upwards at an anglePlato's etymology—A)SPALIEUTIKH/ from A)NASPA=SQAI— is hardly less absurd than that suggested in the translation. The words at an angle are inserted merely to give a reason In English for the words which follow them. has a name in the very likeness of the act and is called angling, which was the object of our present search.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That at all events has been made perfectly clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come, then, let us use this as a pattern and try to find out what a sophist is.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, the first question we asked was whether we must assume that the angler was just a man or was a man with an art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now take this man of ours, Theaetetus. Shall we assume that he is just a man, or by all means really a man of wisdom?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not just a man; for I catch your meaning that he is very far from being wise, although his name implies wisdom.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we must, it seems, assume that he has an art of some kind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, then, what in the world is this art that he has?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Good gracious! Have we failed to notice that the man is akin to the other man?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Who is akin to whom?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The angler to the sophist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: They both seem clearly to me to be a sort of hunters.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is the hunting of the second? We have spoken about the first.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We just now divided hunting as a whole into two classes, and made one division that of swimming creatures and the other that of land-hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the one we discussed, so far as the swimming creatures that live in the water are concerned; but we left the land-hunting undivided, merely remarking that it has many forms.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now up to that point the sophist and the angler proceed together from the starting-point of acquisitive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think they do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But they separate at the point of animal-hunting, where the one turns to the sea and rivers and lakes to hunt the animals in those.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the other turns toward the land and to rivers of a different kind—rivers of wealth and youth, bounteous meadows, as it were—and he intends to coerce the creatures in them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of land-hunting there are two chief divisions.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One is the hunting of tame, the other of wild creatures.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Is there, then, a hunting of tame creatures?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, If man is a tame animal; but make any assumption you like, that there is no tame animal, or that some other tame animal exists but man is a wild one or that man is tame but there is no hunting of man. For the purpose of our definition choose whichever of these statements you think is satisfactory to you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why, Stranger, I think we are a tame animal, and I agree that there is a hunting of man.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, say that the hunting of tame animals is also of two kinds.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How do we justify that assertion?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By defining piracy, man-stealing, tyranny, and the whole art of war all collectively as hunting by force.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And by giving the art of the law courts, of the public platform, and of conversation also a single name and calling them all collectively an art of persuasion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Correct.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now let us say that there are two kinds of persuasion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What kinds?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The one has to do with private persons, the other with the community.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Granted; each of them does form a class.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then again of the hunting of private persons one kind receives pay, and the other brings gifts, does it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Apparently you have never yet paid attention to the lovers' method of hunting.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what respect?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That in addition to their other efforts they give presents to those whom they hunt.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, call this the amatory art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But that part of the paid kind which converses to furnish gratification and makes pleasure exclusively its bait and demands as its pay only maintenance, we might all agree, if I am not mistaken, to call the art of flattery or of making things pleasant.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the class which proposes to carry on its conversations for the sake of virtue and demands its pay in cash—does not this deserve to be called by another name?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what is that name? Try to tell.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is obvious; for I think we have discovered the sophist. And therefore by uttering that word I think I should give him the right name.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, as it seems, according to our present reasoning, Theaetetus, the part of appropriative, coercive, hunting art which hunts animals, land animals, tame animals, man, privately, for pay, is paid in cash, claims to give education, and is a hunt after rich and promising youths, must—so our present argument concludes—be called sophistry.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Most assuredly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But let us look at it in still another way; for the class we are now examining partakes of no mean art, but of a very many-sided one. And we must indeed do so, for in our previous talk it presents an appearance of being, not what we now say it is, but another class.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The acquisitive art was of two sorts, the one the division of hunting, the other that of exchange.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now shall we say that there are two sorts of exchange, the one by gift, the other by sale?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So be it.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall say further that exchange by sale is divided into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We make this distinction—calling the part which sells a man's own productions the selling of one's own, and the other, which exchanges the works of others, exchange.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, that part of exchange which is carried on in the city, amounting to about half of it, is called retailing, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And that which exchanges goods from city to city by purchase and sale is called merchandising?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And have we not observed that one part of merchandising sells and exchanges for cash whatever serves the body for its support and needs, and the other whatever serves the soul?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Perhaps we do not know about the part that has to do with the soul; though I fancy we do understand the other division.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Take, therefore, the liberal artsThe word MOUSIKH/, here rendered “liberal arts,” is much more inclusive than the English word “music,” designating, as it does, nearly all education and culture except the purely physical. In the Athens of Socrates' day many, possibly most, of the teachers of music in this larger sense were foreigners, Greeks, of course, but not Athenians. in general that constantly go about from city to city, bought in one place and carried to another and sold—painting, and conjuring, and the many other things that affect the soul, which are imported and sold partly for its entertainment and partly for its serious needs; we cannot deny that he who carries these about and sells them constitutes a merchant properly so called, no less than he whose business is the sale of food and drink.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then will you give the same name to him who buys up knowledge and goes about from city to city exchanging his wares for money?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One part of this soul-merchandising might very properly be called the art of display, might it not? But since the other part, though no less ridiculous than the first, is nevertheless a traffic in knowledge, must we not call it by some name akin to its business?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now of this merchandising in knowledge the part which has to do with the knowledge of the other arts should be called by one name, and that which has to do with virtue by another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The name of art-merchant would fit the one who trades in the other arts, and now do you be so good as to tell the name of him who trades in virtue.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: And what other name could one give, without making a mistake, than that which is the object of our present investigation—the sophist?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: No other. Come then, let us now summarize the matter by saying that sophistry has appeared a second time as that part of acquisitive art, art of exchange, of trafficking, of merchandising, of soul-merchandising which deals in words and knowledge, and trades in virtue.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But there is a third case: If a man settled down here in town and proposed to make his living by selling these same wares of knowledge, buying some of them and making others himself, you would, I fancy, not call him by any other name than that which you used a moment ago.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then also that part of acquisitive art which proceeds by exchange, and by sale, whether as mere retail trade or the sale of one's own productions, no matter which, so long as it is of the class of merchandising in knowledge, you will always, apparently, call sophistry.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I must do so, for I have to follow where the argument leads.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us examine further and see if the class we are now pursuing has still another aspect, of similar nature.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of what nature?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We agreed that fighting was a division of acquisitive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we did.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is quite fitting to divide it into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Tell what the parts are.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us call one part of it the competitive and the other the pugnacious.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is reasonable and fitting to give to that part of the pugnacious which consists of bodily contests some such name as violent.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what other name than controversy shall we give to the contests of words?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No other.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But controversy must be divided into two kinds.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Whenever long speeches are opposed by long speeches on questions of justice and injustice in public, that is forensic controversy.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But that which is carried on among private persons and is cut up into little bits by means of questions and their answers, we are accustomed to call argumentation, are we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We are.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And that part of argumentation which deals with business contracts, in which there is controversy, to be sure, but it is carried on informally and without rules of art—all that must be considered a distinct class, now that our argument has recognized it as different from the rest, but it received no name from our predecessors, nor does it now deserve to receive one from us.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True; for the divisions into which it falls are too small and too miscellaneous.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But that which possesses rules of art and carries on controversy about abstract justice and injustice and the rest in general terms, we are accustomed to call disputation, are we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, of disputation, one sort wastes money, the other makes money.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us try to tell the name by which we must call each of these.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we must do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Presumably the kind which causes a man to neglect his own affairs for the pleasure of engaging in it, but the style of which causes no pleasure to most of his hearers, is, in my opinion, called by no other name than garrulity.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is about what it is called.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the opposite of this, the kind which makes money from private disputes—try now, for it is your turn, to give its name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What other answer could one give without making a mistake, than that now again for the fourth time that wonderful being whom we have so long been pursuing has turned up—the sophist!

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, and the sophist is nothing else, apparently, than the money-making class of the disputatious, argumentative, controversial, pugnacious, combative, acquisitive art, as our argument has now again stated.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you see the truth of the statement that this creature is many-sided and, as the saying is, not to be caught with one hand?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Then we must catch him with both.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, we must, and must go at it with all our might, by following another track of his—in this way. Tell me; of the expressions connected with menial occupations some are in common use, are they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, many. But to which of the many does your question refer?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: To such as these: we say “sift” and “strain” and “winnow” and “separate.”Apparently a term descriptive of some part of the process of weaving; cf. Plat. Crat. 338b.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And besides these there are “card” and “comb” and “beat the web” and countless other technical terms which we know. Is it not so?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why do you use these as examples and ask about them all? What do you wish to show in regard to them?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: All those that I have mentioned imply a notion of division.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since there is, accorling to my reckoning, one art involved in all of these operations, let us give it one name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What shall we call it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The art of discrimination.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now see if we can discover two divisions of this.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You demand quick thinking, for a boy like me.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet, in the instance of discrimination just mentioned there was, first, the separation of worse from better, and, secondly, of like from like.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, as you now express it, that is pretty clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now I know no common name for the second kind of discrimination; but I do know the name of the kind which retains the better and throws away the worse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Every such discrimination, as I think, is universally called a sort of purification.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, so it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And could not anyone see that purification is of two kinds?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, perhaps, in time; but still I do not see it now.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Still there are many kinds of purifications of bodies, and they may all properly be included under one name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they and what is the name?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The purification of living creatures, having to do with impurities within the body, such as are successfully discriminated by gymnastics and medicine, and with those outside of the body, not nice to speak of, such as are attended to by the bath-keeper's art; and the purification of inanimate bodies, which is the special care of the fuller's art and in general of the art of exterior decoration; this, with its petty subdivisions, has taken on many names which seem ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Certainly they do, Theaetetus. However, the method of argument is neither more nor less concerned with the art of medicine than with that of sponging, but is indifferent if the one benefits us little, the other greatly by its purifying. It endeavors to understand what is related and what is not related in all arts, for the purpose of acquiring intelligence; and therefore it honors them all equally and does not in making comparisons think one more ridiculous than another, and does not consider him who employs, as his example of hunting, the art of generalship, any more dignified than him who employs the art of louse-catching, but only, for the most part, as more pretentious. And now as to your question, what name we shall give to all the activities whose function it is to purify the body, whether animate or inanimate, it will not matter at all to our method what name sounds finest; it cares only to unite under one name all purifications of everything else and to keep them separate from the purification of the soul. For it has in our present discussion been trying to separate this purification definitely from the rest, if we understand its desire.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But I do understand and I agree that there are two kinds of purification and that one kind is the purification of the soul, which is separate from that of the body.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Most excellent. Now pay attention to the next point and try again to divide the term.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In whatever way you suggest, I will try to help you in making the division.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do we say that wickedness is distinct from virtue in the soul?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And purification was retaining the one and throwing out whatever is bad anywhere?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence whenever we find any removal of evil from the soul, we shall be speaking properly if we call that a purification.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very properly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must say that there are two kinds of evil in the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What kinds?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The one is comparable to a disease in the body, the other to a deformity.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Perhaps you have not considered that disease and discord are the same thing?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not know what reply I ought to make to this, either.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is that because you think discord is anything else than the disagreement of the naturally related, brought about by some corruption?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No; I think it is nothing else.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But is deformity anything else than the presence of the quality of disproportion, which is always ugly?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Nothing else at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then; do we not see that in the souls of worthless men opinions are opposed to desires, anger to pleasures, reason to pain, and all such things to one another?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they are, decidedly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yet they must all be naturally related.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we shall be right if we say that wickedness is a discord and disease of the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if things which partake of motion and aim at some particular mark pass beside the mark and miss it on every occasion when they try to hit it, shall we say that this happens to them through right proportion to one another or, on the contrary, through disproportion?The connection between disproportion and missing the mark is not obvious. The explanation that a missile (e.g. an arrow) which is not evenly balanced will not fly straight, fails to take account of the words PRO\S A)/LLHLA. The idea seems rather to be that moving objects of various sizes, shapes, and rates of speed must interfere with each other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently through disproportion.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But yet we know that every soul, if ignorant of anything, is ignorant against its will.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very much so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now being ignorant is nothing else than the aberration of a soul that aims at truth, when the understanding passes beside the mark.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must regard a foolish soul as deformed and ill-proportioned.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then there are, it appears, these two kinds of evils in the soul, one, which people call wickedness, which is very clearly a disease.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the other they call ignorance, but they are not willing to acknowledge that it is vice, when it arises only in the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It must certainly be admitted, though I disputed it when you said it just now, that there are two kinds of vice in the soul, and that cowardice, intemperance, and injustice must all alike be considered a disease in us, and the widespread and various condition of ignorance must be regarded as a deformity.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In the case of the body there are two arts which have to do with these two evil conditions, are there not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For deformity there is gymnastics, and for disease medicine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence for insolence and injustice and cowardice is not the corrective art the one of all arts most closely related to Justice?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Probably it is, at least according to the judgement of mankind.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And for all sorts of ignorance is there any art it would be more correct to suggest than that of instruction?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, none.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come now, think. Shall we say that there is only one kind of instruction, or that there are more and that two are the most important?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I am thinking.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I think we can find out most quickly in this way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: By seeing whether ignorance admits of being cut in two in the middle; for if ignorance turns out to be twofold, it is clear that instruction must also consist of two parts, one for each part of ignorance.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, can you see what you are now looking for?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I at any rate think I do see one large and grievous kind of ignorance, separate from the rest, and as weighty as all the other parts put together.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Thinking that one knows a thing when one does not know it. Through this, I believe, all the mistakes of the mind are caused in all of us.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And furthermore to this kind of ignorance alone the name of stupidity is given.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now what name is to be given to that part of instruction which gets rid of this?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think, Stranger, that the other part is called instruction in handicraft, and that this part is here at Athens through our influence called education.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so it is, Theaetetus, among nearly all the Hellenes. But we must examine further and see whether it is one and indivisible or still admits of division important enough to have a name.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we must see about that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I think there is still a way in which this also may be divided.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: On what principle?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of instruction in arguments one method seems to be rougher, and the other section smoother.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What shall we call each of these?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The venerable method of our fathers, which they generally employed towards their sons, and which many still employ, of sometimes showing anger at their errors and sometimes more gently exhorting them—that would most properly be called as a whole admonition.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: On the other hand, some appear to have convinced themselves that all ignorance is involuntary, and that he who thinks himself wise would never be willing to learn any of those things in which he believes he is clever, and that the admonitory kind of education takes a deal of trouble and accomplishes little.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: They are quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So they set themselves to cast out the conceit of cleverness in another way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: They question a man about the things about which he thinks he is talking sense when he is talking nonsense; then they easily discover that his opinions are like those of men who wander, and in their discussions they collect those opinions and compare them with one another, and by the comparison they show that they contradict one another about the same things, in relation to the same things and in respect to the same things. But those who see this grow angry with themselves and gentle towards others, and this is the way in which they are freed from their high and obstinate opinions about themselves. The process of freeing them, moreover, affords the greatest pleasure to the listeners and the most lasting benefit to him who is subjected to it. For just as physicians who care for the body believe that the body cannot get benefit from any food offered to it until all obstructions are removed, so, my boy, those who purge the soul believe that the soul can receive no benefit from any teachings offered to it until someone by cross-questioning reduces him who is cross-questioned to an attitude of modesty, by removing the opinions that obstruct the teachings, and thus purges him and makes him think that he knows only what he knows, and no more.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is surely the best and most reasonable state of mind.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For all these reasons, Theaetetus, we must assert that cross-questioning is the greatest and most efficacious of all purifications, and that he who is not cross-questioned, even though he be the Great King, has not been purified of the greatest taints, and is therefore uneducated and deformed in those things in which he who is to be truly happy ought to be most pure and beautiful.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perfectly true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, who are those who practise this art? I am afraid to say the sophists.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Lest we grant them too high a meed of honor.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But the description you have just given is very like someone of that sort.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, and a wolf is very like a dog, the wildest like the tamest of animals. But the cautious man must be especially on his guard in the matter of resemblances, for they are very slippery things. However, let us agree that they are the sophists; for I think the strife will not be about petty discriminations when people are sufficiently on their guard.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, probably not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let it be agreed that part of the discriminating art is purification, and as part of purification let that which is concerned with the soul be separated off, and as part of this, instruction, and as part of instruction, education; and let us agree that the cross-questioning of empty conceit of wisdom, which has come to light in our present discussion, is nothing else than the true-born art of sophistry.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Let us agree to all that; but the sophist has by this time appeared to be so many things that I am at a loss to know what in the world to say he really is, with any assurance that I am speaking the truth.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: No wonder you are at a loss. But it is fair to suppose that by this time he is still more at a loss to know how he can any longer elude our argument; for the proverb is right which says it is not easy to escape all the wrestler's grips. So now we must attack him with redoubled vigor.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: First, then, let us stop to take breath and while we are resting let us count up the number of forms in which the sophist has appeared to us. First, I believe, he was found to be a paid hunter after the young and wealthy.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And secondly a kind of merchant in articles of knowledge for the soul.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And thirdly did he not turn up as a retailer of these same articles of knowledge?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, and fourthly we found he was a seller of his own productions of knowledge.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Your memory is good; but I will try to recall the fifth case myself. He was an athlete in contests of words, who had taken for his own the art of disputation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, he was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The sixth case was doubtful, but nevertheless we agreed to consider him a purger of souls, who removes opinions that obstruct learning.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then do you see that when a man appears to know many things, but is called by the name of a single art, there is something wrong about this impression, and that, in fact, the person who labors under this impression in connexion with any art is clearly unable to see the common principle of the art, to which all these kinds of knowledge pertain, so that he calls him who possesses them by many names instead of one?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Something like that is very likely to be the case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must not let that happen to us in our search through lack of diligence. So let us first take up again one of our statements about the sophist. For there is one of them which seemed to me to designate him most plainly.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Which was it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I think we said he was a disputer.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And did we not also say that he taught this same art of disputing to others?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now let us examine and see what the subjects are about which such men say they make their pupils able to dispute. Let us begin our examination at the beginning with this question: Is it about divine things which are invisible to others that they make people able to dispute?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is their reputation, at any rate.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about the visible things of earth and heaven and the like?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Those are included, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And furthermore in private conversations, when the talk is about generation and being in general, we know (do we not?) that they are clever disputants themselves and impart equal ability to others.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about laws and public affairs in general? Do they not promise to make men able to argue about those?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, for nobody, to speak broadly, would attend their classes if they did not make that promise.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: However in all arts jointly and severally what the professional ought to answer to every opponent is written down somewhere and published that he who will may learn.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You seem to refer to the text-books of Protagoras on wrestling and the other arts.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, my friend, and to those of many other authors. But is not the art of disputation, in a word, a trained ability for arguing about all things?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, at any rate, it does not seem to leave much out.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For heaven's sake, my boy, do you think that is possible? For perhaps you young people may look at the matter with sharper vision than our duller sight.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean and just what do you refer to? I do not yet understand your question.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I ask whether it is possible for a man to know all things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: If that were possible, Stranger, ours would indeed be a blessed race.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: How, then, can one who is himself ignorant say anything worth while in arguing with one who knows?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: He cannot at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then what in the world can the magical power of the sophistical art be?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Magical power in what respect?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In the way in which they are able to make young men think that they themselves are in all matters the wisest of men. For it is clear that if they neither disputed correctly nor seemed to the young men to do so, or again if they did seem to dispute rightly but were not considered wiser on that account, nobody, to quote from you,Cf. Plat. Theaet. 232d. would care to pay them money to become their pupil in these subjects.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now people do care to do so?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very much.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, for they are supposed, I fancy, to have knowledge themselves of the things about which they dispute.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And they do that about all things, do they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then they appear to their pupils to be wise in all things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Though they are not; for that was shown to be impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is a sort of knowledge based upon mere opinion that the sophist has been shown to possess about all things, not true knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly; and I shouldn't be surprised if that were the most accurate statement we have made about him so far.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us then take a clearer example to explain this.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What sort of an example?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: This one; and try to pay attention and to give a very careful answer to my question.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is the question?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If anyone should say that by virtue of a single art he knew how, not to assert or dispute, but to do and make all things—

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean by all things?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You fail to grasp the very beginning of what I said; for apparently you do not understand the word “all.”

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, I do not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I mean you and me among the “all,” and the other animals besides, and the trees.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If one should say that he would make you and me and all other created beings.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What would he mean by “making”? Evidently you will not say that he means a husbandman; for you said he was a maker of animals also.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, and of sea and earth and heaven and gods and everything else besides; and, moreover, he makes them all quickly and sells them for very little.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: This is some joke of yours.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes? And when a man says that he knows all things and can teach them to another for a small price in a little time, must we not consider that a joke?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Surely we must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And is there any more artistic or charming kind of joke than the imitative kind?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not; for it is of very frequent occurrence and, if I may say so, most diverse. Your expression is very comprehensive.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so we recognize that he who professes to be able by virtue of a single art to make all things will be able by virtue of the painter's art, to make imitations which have the same names as the real things, and by showing the pictures at a distance will be able to deceive the duller ones among young children into the belief that he is perfectly able to accomplish in fact whatever he wishes to do.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, may we not expect to find that there is another art which has to do with words, by virtue of which it is possible to bewitch the young through their ears with words while they are still standing at a distance from the realities of truth, by exhibiting to them spoken images of all things, so as to make it seem that they are true and that the speaker is the wisest of all men in all things?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why should there not be such another art?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now most of the hearers, Theaetetus, when they have lived longer and grown older, will perforce come closer to realities and will be forced by sad experienceApparently a reference to a proverbial expression. Cf. Hes. WD 216 E)/GNW PAQW/N; Herodotus, 1.207 TA\ PAQH/MATA MAQH/MATA. openly to lay hold on realities; they will have to change the opinions which they had at first accepted, so that what was great will appear small and what was easy, difficult, and all the apparent truths in arguments will be turned topsy-turvy by the facts that have come upon them in real life. Is not this true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, at least so far as one of my age can judge. But I imagine I am one of those who are still standing at a distance.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Therefore all of us elders here will try, and are now trying, to bring you as near as possible without the sad experience. So answer this question about the sophist: Is this now clear, that he is a kind of a juggler, an imitator of realities, or are we still uncertain whether he may not truly possess the knowledge of all the things about which he seems to be able to argue?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How could that be, my dear sir? Surely it is pretty clear by this time from what has been said that he is one of those whose business is entertainment.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That is to say, he must be classed as a juggler and imitator.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course he must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Look sharp, then; it is now our business not to let the beast get away again, for we have almost got him into a kind of encircling net of the devices we employ in arguments about such subjects, so that he will not now escape the next thing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What next thing?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The conclusion that he belongs to the class of conjurers.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I agree to that opinion of him, too.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is decided, then, that we will as quickly as possible divide the image-making art and go down into it, and if the sophist stands his ground against us at first, we will seize him by the orders of reason, our king, then deliver him up to the king and display his capture. But if he tries to take cover in any of the various sections of the imitative art, we must follow him, always dividing the section into which he has retreated, until he is caught. For assuredly neither he nor any other creature will ever boast of having escaped from pursuers who are able to follow up the pursuit in detail and everywhere in this methodical way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right. That is what we must do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: To return, then, to our previous method of division, I think I see this time also two classes of imitation, but I do not yet seem to be able to make out in which of them the form we are seeking is to be found.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Please first make the division and tell us what two classes you mean.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I see the likeness-making art as one part of imitation. This is met with, as a rule, whenever anyone produces the imitation by following the proportions of the original in length, breadth, and depth, and giving, besides, the appropriate colors to each part.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, but do not all imitators try to do this?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Not those who produce some large work of sculpture or painting. For if they reproduced the true proportions of beautiful forms, the upper parts, you know, would seem smaller and the lower parts larger than they ought, because we see the former from a distance, the latter from near at hand.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So the artists abandon the truth and give their figures not the actual proportions but those which seem to be beautiful, do they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That, then, which is other, but like, we may fairly call a likeness, may we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the part of imitation which is concerned with such things, is to be called, as we called it before, likeness-making?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is to be so called.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now then, what shall we call that which appears, because it is seen from an unfavorable position, to be like the beautiful, but which would not even be likely to resemble that which it claims to be like, if a person were able to see such large works adequately? Shall we not call it, since it appears, but is not like, an appearance?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And this is very common in painting and in all imitation?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And to the art which produces appearance, but not likeness, the most correct name we could give would be “fantastic art,” would it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: These, then, are the two forms of the image-making art that I meant, the likeness-making and the fantastic.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But I was uncertain before in which of the two the sophist should be placed, and even now I cannot see clearly. The fellow is really wonderful and very difficult to keep in sight, for once more, in the very cleverest manner he has withdrawn into a baffling classification where it is hard to track him.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you assent because you recognize the fact, or did the force of habit hurry you along to a speedy assent?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean, and why did you say that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We are really, my dear friend, engaged in a very difficult investigation; for the matter of appearing and seeming, but not being, and of saying things, but not true ones—all this is now and always has been very perplexing. You see, Theaetetus, it is extremely difficult to understand how a man is to say or think that falsehood really exists and in saying this not be involved in contradiction.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
Theaetetus
sp.p: Assume my consent to anything you wish. Consider only the argument, how it may best be pursued; follow your own course, and take me along with you.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Very well, then. Now tell me; do we venture to use the phrase absolute not-being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If, then, not merely for the sake of discussion or as a joke, but seriously, one of his pupils were asked to consider and answer the question “To what is the designation 'not-being' to be applied?” how do we think he would reply to his questioner, and how would he apply the term, for what purpose, and to what object?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is a difficult question; I may say that for a fellow like me it is unanswerable.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But this is clear, anyhow, that the term “not-being” cannot be applied to any being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if not to being, then it could not properly be applied to something, either.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How could it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And this is plain to us, that we always use the word “something” of some being, for to speak of “something” in the abstract, naked, as it were, and disconnected from all beings is impossible, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You assent because you recognize that he who says something must say some one thing?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And you will agree that “something” or “some” in the singular is the sign of one, in the dual of two, and in the plural of many.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And he who says not something, must quite necessarily say absolutely nothing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite necessarily.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we cannot even concede that such a person speaks, but says nothing? We must even declare that he who undertakes to say “not-being” does not speak at all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The argument could go no further in perplexity.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Boast not too soon! For there still remains, my friend, the first and greatest of perplexities. It affects the very beginning of the matter.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean? Do not hesitate to speak.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: To that which is may be added or attributed some other thing which is?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But shall we assert that to that which is not anything which is can be attributed?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now we assume that all number is among the things which are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, if anything can be assumed to be.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us not even undertake to attribute either the singular or the plural of number to not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We should, apparently, not be right in undertaking that, as our argument shows.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: How then could a man either utter in speech or even so much as conceive in his mind things which are not, or not-being, apart from number?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Tell me how number is involved in such conceptions.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When we say “things which are not,” do we not attribute plurality to them?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in saying “a thing which is not,” do we not equally attribute the singular number?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Obviously.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet we assert that it is neither right nor fair to undertake to attribute being to not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you see, then, that it is impossible rightly to utter or to say or to think of not-being without any attribute, but it is a thing inconceivable, inexpressible, unspeakable, irrational?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Absolutely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then was I mistaken just now in saying that the difficulty I was going to speak of was the greatest in our subject.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But is there a still greater one that we can mention?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Why, my dear fellow, don't you see, by the very arguments we have used, that not-being reduces him who would refute it to such difficulties that when he attempts to refute it he is forced to contradict himself?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean? Speak still more clearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You must not look for more clearness in me; for although I maintained that not-being could have nothing to do with either the singular or the plural number, I spoke of it just now, and am still speaking of it, as one; for I say “that which is not.” You understand surely?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again a little while ago I said it was inexpressible, unspeakable, irrational. Do you follow me?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then when I undertook to attach the verb “to be” to not-being I was contradicting what I said before.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then; when I attached this verb to it, did I not address it in the singular?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And when I called it irrational, inexpressible, and unspeakable, I addressed my speech to it as singular.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course you did.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we say that, if one is to speak correctly, one must not define it as either singular or plural, and must not even call it “it” at all; for even by this manner of referring to it one would be giving it the form of the singular.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But poor me, what can anyone say of me any longer? For you would find me now, as always before, defeated in the refutation of not-being. So, as I said before, we must not look to me for correctness of speech about not-being. But come now, let us look to you for it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Come, I beg of you, make a sturdy effort, young man as you are, and try with might and main to say something correctly about not-being, without attributing to it either existence or unity or plurality.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But I should be possessed of great and absurd eagerness for the attempt, if I were to undertake it with your experience before my eyes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, if you like, let us say no more of you and me; but until we find someone who can accomplish this, let us confess that the sophist has in most rascally fashion hidden himself in a place we cannot explore.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That seems to be decidedly the case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so, if we say he has an art, as it were, of making appearances, he will easily take advantage of our poverty of terms to make a counter attack, twisting our words to the opposite meaning; when we call him an image-maker, he will ask us what we mean by “image,” exactly. So, Theaetetus, we must see what reply is to be made to the young man's question.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Obviously we shall reply that we mean the images in water and in mirrors, and those in paintings, too, and sculptures, and all the other things of the same sort.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is evident, Theaetetus, that you never saw a sophist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: He will make you think his eyes are shut or he has none at all.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When you give this answer, if you speak of something in mirrors or works of art, he will laugh at your words, when you talk to him as if he could see. He will feign ignorance of mirrors and water and of sight altogether, and will question you only about that which is deduced from your words.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That which exists throughout all these things which you say are many but which you saw fit to call by one name, when you said “image” of them all, as if they were all one thing. So speak and defend yourself. Do not give way to the man at all.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why, Stranger, what can we say an image is, except another such thing fashioned in the likeness of the true one?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you mean another such true one, or in what sense did you say “such”?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not a true one by any means, but only one like the true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And by the true you mean that which really is?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the not true is the opposite of the true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That which is like, then, you say does not really exist, if you say it is not true.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But it does exist, in a way.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But not truly, you mean.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, except that it is really a likeness.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then what we call a likeness, though not really existing, really does exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not-being does seem to have got into some such entanglement with being, and it is very absurd.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Of course it is absurd. You see, at any rate, how by this interchange of words the many-headed sophist has once more forced us against our will to admit that not-being exists in a way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I see that very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, how can we define his art without contradicting ourselves?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why do you say that? What are you afraid of?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When, in talking about appearance, we say that he deceives and that his art is an art of deception, shall we say that our mind is misled by his art to hold a false opinion, or what shall we say?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We shall say that. What else could we say?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But, again, false opinion will be that which thinks the opposite of reality, will it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You mean, then, that false opinion thinks things which are not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Necessarily.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Does it think that things which are not, are not, or that things which are not at all, in some sense are?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It must think that things which are not in some sense are—that is, if anyone is ever to think falsely at all, even in a slight degree.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And does it not also think that things which certainly are, are not at all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And this too is falsehood?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is,

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And therefore a statement will likewise be considered false, if it declares that things which are, are not, or that things which are not, are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what other way could a statement be made false?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Virtually in no other way; but the sophist will not assent to this. Or how can any reasonable man assent to it, when the expressions we just agreed upon were previously agreed to be inexpressible, unspeakable, irrational, and inconceivable? Do we understand his meaning, Theaetetus?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course we understand that he will say we are contradicting our recent statements, since we dare to say that falsehood exists in opinions and words; for he will say that we are thus forced repeatedly to attribute being to not-being, although we agreed a while ago that nothing could be more impossible than that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You are quite right to remind me. But I think it is high time to consider what ought to be done about the sophist; for you see how easily and repeatedly he can raise objections and difficulties, if we conduct our search by putting him in the guild of false-workers and jugglers.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, we have gone through only a small part of them, and they are, if I may say so, infinite.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It would, apparently, be impossible to catch the sophist, if that is the case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, shall we weaken and give up the struggle now?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, I say; we must not do that, if we can in any way get the slightest hold of the fellow.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Will you then pardon me, and, as your words imply, be content if I somehow withdraw just for a short distance from this strong argument of his?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course I will.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I have another still more urgent request to make of you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do not assume that I am becoming a sort of parricide.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In defending myself I shall have to test the theory of my father Parmenides, and contend forcibly that after a fashion not-being is and on the other hand in a sense being is not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is plain that some such contention is necessary.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, plain even to a blind man, as they say; for unless these statements are either disproved or accepted, no one who speaks about false words, or false opinion—whether images or likenesses or imitations or appearances—about the arts which have to do with them, can ever help being forced to contradict himself and make himself ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so we must take courage and attack our father's theory here and now, or else, if any scruples prevent us from doing this, we must give the whole thing up.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But nothing in the world must prevent us.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then I have a third little request to make of you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You have only to utter it.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I said a while ago that I always have been too faint-hearted for the refutation of this theory, and so I am now.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, so you did.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I am afraid that on account of what I have said you will think I am mad because I have at once reversed my position. You see it is for your sake that I am going to undertake the refutation, if I succeed in it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I certainly shall not think you are doing anything improper if you proceed to your refutation and proof; so go ahead boldly, so far as that is concerned.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, what would be a good beginning of a perilous argument? Ah, my boy, I believe the way we certainly must take is this.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must first examine the points which now seem clear, lest we may have fallen into some confusion about them and may therefore carelessly agree with one another, thinking that we are judging correctly.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Express your meaning more clearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It seems to me that Parmenides and all who ever undertook a critical definition of the number and nature of realities have talked to us rather carelessly.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Every one of them seems to tell us a story, as if we were children. One says there are three principles, that some of them are sometimes waging a sort of war with each other, and sometimes become friends and marry and have children and bring them up; and another says there are two, wet and dry or hot and cold, which he settles together and unites in marriage.This refers apparently to Pherecydes and the early lonians. And the Eleatic sect in our region, beginning with Xenophanes and even earlier, have their story that all things, as they are called, are really one. Then some IonianHeracleitus and his followers. and later some SicilianEmpedocles and his disciples. Muses reflected that it was safest to combine the two tales and to say that being is many and one, and is (or are) held together by enmity and friendship. For the more strenuous Muses say it is always simultaneously coming together and separating; but the gentler ones relaxed the strictness of the doctrine of perpetual strife; they say that the all is sometimes one and friendly, under the influence of Aphrodite, and sometimes many and at variance with itself by reason of some sort of strife. Now whether any of them spoke the truth in all this, or not, it is harsh and improper to impute to famous men of old such a great wrong as falsehood. But one assertion can be made without offence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That they paid too little attention and consideration to the mass of people like ourselves. For they go on to the end, each in his own way, without caring whether their arguments carry us along with them, or whether we are left behind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When one of them says in his talk that many, or one, or two are, or have become, or are becoming, and again speaks of hot mingling with cold, and in some other part of his discourse suggests separations and combinations, for heaven's sake, Theaetetus, do you ever understand what they mean by any of these things? I used to think, when I was younger, that I understood perfectly whenever anyone used this term “not-being,” which now perplexes us. But you see what a slough of perplexity we are in about it now.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I see.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And perhaps our minds are in this same condition as regards being also; we may think that it is plain sailing and that we understand when the word is used, though we are in difficulties about not-being, whereas really we understand equally little of both.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we may say the same of all the subjects about which we have been speaking.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We will consider most of them later, if you please, but now the greatest and foremost chief of them must be considered.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean? Or, obviously, do you mean that we must first investigate the term “being,” and see what those who use it think it signifies?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You have caught my meaning at once, Theaetetus. For I certainly do mean that this is the best method for us to use, by questioning them directly, as if they were present in person; so here goes: Come now, all you who say that hot and cold or any two such principles are the universe, what is this that you attribute to both of them when you say that both and each are? What are we to understand by this “being” (or “are”) of yours? Is this a third principle besides those two others, and shall we suppose that the universe is three, and not two any longer, according to your doctrine? For surely when you call one only of the two “being” you do not mean that both of them equally are; for in both cases“In both cases,” i.e. whether you say that one only is or that both are, they would both be one, namely being. they would pretty certainly be one and not two.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, do you wish to call both of them together being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But, friends, we will say, even in that way you would very clearly be saying that the two are one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are perfectly right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since we are in perplexity, do you tell us plainly what you wish to designate when you say “being.” For it is clear that you have known this all along, whereas we formerly thought we knew, but are now perplexed.
