So first give us this information, that we may not think we understand what you say, when the exact opposite is the case.— If we speak in this way and make this request of them and of all who say that the universe is more than one, shall we, my boy, be doing anything improper?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not in the least.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, must we not, so far as we can, try to learn from those who say that the universe is oneThe Eleatic Zeno and his school. what they mean when they say “being”?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course we must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let them answer this question: Do you say that one only is? We do, they will say; will they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, do you give the name of being to anything?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is it what you call “one,” using two names for the same thing, or how is this?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is their next answer, Stranger?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is plain, Theaetetus, that he who maintains their theory will not find it the easiest thing in the world to reply to our present question or to any other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is rather ridiculous to assert that two names exist when you assert that nothing exists but unity.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in general there would be no sense in accepting the statement that a name has any existence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Because he who asserts that the name is other than the thing, says that there are two entities.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, if he asserts that the name is the same as the thing, he will be obliged to say that it is the name of nothing, or if he says it is the name of something, the name will turn out to be the name of a name merely and of nothing else.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the one will turn out to be the name of one and also the one of the name.In other words, “one,” considered as a word, will be the name of unity, but considered as a reality, it will be the unity of which the word “one” is the name. The sentence is made somewhat difficult of comprehension, doubtless for the purpose of indicating the confusion caused by the identification of the name wlth the thing.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Necessarily.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And will they say that the whole is other than the one which exists or the same with it?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course they will and do say it is the same.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p:
If then the whole is, as Parmenides says,
On all sides like the mass of a well-rounded sphere, equally weighted in every direction from the middle; for neither greater nor less must needs be on this or that,Parmenides Fr. 8.43then being, being such as he describes it, has a center and extremes, and, having these, must certainly have parts, must it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But yet nothing hinders that which has parts from possessing the attribute of unity in all its parts and being in this way one, since it is all and whole.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But is it not impossible for that which is in this condition to be itself absolute unity?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Why surely that which is really one must, according to right reason, be affirmed to be absolutely without parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But such a unity consisting of many parts will not harmonize with reason.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we agree that being is one and a whole because it has the attribute of unity, or shall we deny that being is a whole at all?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is a hard choice that you offer me.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That is very true; for being, having in a way had unity imposed upon it, will evidently not be the same as unity, and the all will be more than one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, if being is not a whole through having had the attribute of unity imposed upon it, and the absolute whole exists, then it turns out that being lacks something of being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so, by this reasoning, since being is deprived of being, it will be not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it will.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again the all becomes more than the one, since being and the whole have acquired each its own nature.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if the whole does not exist at all, being is involved in the same difficulties as before, and besides not existing it could not even have ever come into existence

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That which comes into existence always comes into existence as a whole. Therefore no one who does not reckon the whole among things that are can speak of existence or generation as being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That certainly seems to be true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And moreover, that which is not a whole cannot have any quantity at all; for if it has any quantity, whatever that quantity may be, it must necessarily be of that quantity as a whole.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so countless other problems, each one involving infinite difficulties, will confront him who says that being is, whether it be two or only one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The problems now in sight make that pretty clear; for each leads up to another which brings greater and more grievous wandering in connection with whatever has previously been said.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now we have not discussed all those who treat accurately of being and not-beingThe Ionic philosophers, the Eleatics, Heracleitus, Empedocles, the Megarians, Gorgias, Protagoras, and Antisthenes all discussed the problem of being and not-being.; however, let this suffice. But we must turn our eyes to those whose doctrines are less precise, that we may know from all sources that it is no easier to define the nature of being than that of not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well, then, we must proceed towards those others also.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And indeed there seems to be a battle like that of the gods and the giants going on among them, because of their disagreement about existence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Some of themThe atomists (Leucippus, Democritus, and their followers), who taught that nothing exists except atoms and the void. Possibly there is a covert reference to Aristippus who was, like Plato, a pupil of Socrates. drag down everything from heaven and the invisible to earth, actually grasping rocks and trees with their hands; for they lay their hands on all such things and maintain stoutly that that alone exists which can be touched and handled; for they define existence and body, or matter, as identical, and if anyone says that anything else, which has no body, exists, they despise him utterly, and will not listen to any other theory than their own.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Terrible men they are of whom you speak. I myself have met with many of them.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Therefore those who contend against them defend themselves very cautiously with weapons derived from the invisible world above, maintaining forcibly that real existence consists of certain ideas which are only conceived by the mind and have no body. But the bodies of their opponents, and that which is called by them truth, they break up into small fragments in their arguments, calling them, not existence, but a kind of generation combined with motion. There is always, Theaetetus, a tremendous battle being fought about these questions between the two parties.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, therefore, get from each party in turn a statement in defence of that which they regard as being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How shall we get it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is comparatively easy to get it from those who say that it consists in ideas, for they are peaceful folk; but from those who violently drag down everything into matter, it is more difficult, perhaps even almost impossible, to get it. However, this is the way I think we must deal with them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Our first duty would be to make them really better, if it were in any way possible; but if this cannot be done, let us pretend that they are better, by assuming that they would be willing to answer more in accordance with the rules of dialectic than they actually are. For the acknowledgement of anything by better men is more valid than if made by worse men. But it is not these men that we care about; we merely seek the truth.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now tell them, assuming that they have become better, to answer you, and do you interpret what they say.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I will do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let them tell whether they say there is such a thing as a mortal animal.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course they do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And they agree that this is a body with a soul in it, do they not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Giving to soul a place among things which exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, do they not say that one soul is just and another unjust, one wise and another foolish?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And do they not say that each soul becomes just by the possession and presence of justice, and the opposite by the possession and presence of the opposite?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they agree to this also.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But surely they will say that that which is capable of becoming present or absent exists.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, they say that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Granting, then, that justice and wisdom and virtue in general and their opposites exist, and also, of course, the soul in which they become present, do they say that any of these is visible and tangible, or that they are all invisible?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That none of them is visible, or pretty nearly that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now here are some other questions. Do they say they possess any body?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: They no longer answer the whole of that question in the same way. They say they believe the soul itself has a sort of body, but as to wisdom and the other several qualities about which you ask, they have not the face either to confess that they have no existence or to assert that they are all bodies.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is clear, Theaetetus, that our men have grown better; for the aboriginal sons of the dragon's teethThis refers to the story of Cadmus, who killed a dragon and then sowed its teeth, from which sprang fierce warriors to be his companions. Born of the dragon's teeth and of earth, they would naturally be of the earth, earthy. among them would not shrink from any such utterance; they would maintain that nothing which they cannot squeeze with their hands has any existence at all.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is pretty nearly what they believe.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us question them further; for if they are willing to admit that any existence, no matter how small, is incorporeal, that is enough. They will then have to tell what is which is inherent in the incorporeal and the corporeal alike, and which they have in mind when they say that both exit. Perhaps they would be at a loss for an answer; and if they are in that condition, consider whether they might not accept a suggestion if we offered it, and might not agree that the nature of being is as follows.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it? Speak, and we shall soon know.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I suggest that everything which possesses any power of any kind, eithr to produce a change in anything of any nature or to be affected even in the least degree by the slightest cause, though it be only on one occasion, has real existence. For I set up as a definition which defines being, that it is nothing else but power.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Well, since they have at the moment nothing better of their own to offer, they accept this.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Good; for perhaps later something else may occur to them and to us. As between them and us, then, let us asume that this is for the present agreed upon and settled.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It is settled.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us go to the others, the friends of ideas; and do you interpret for us their doctrines also.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I will.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You distinguish in your speech between generation and being, do you not?i.e., between the process of coming into existence and existence itself. It is difficult to determine exactly who the idealists are whose doctrines are here discussed. Possibly Plato is restating or amending some of his own earlier beliefs.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And you say that with the body, by means of perception, we participate in generation, and with the soul, by means of thought, we participate in real being, which last is always unchanged and the same, whereas generation is different at different times.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is what we say.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But, most excellent men, how shall we define this participation which you attribute to both? Is it not that of which we were just speaking?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: A passive or active condition arising out of some power which is derived from a combination of elements. Possibly, Theaetetus, you do not hear their reply to this, but I hear it, perhaps, because I am used to them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it, then, that they say?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: They do not concede to us what we said just now to the aboriginal giants about being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What was it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We set up as a satisfactory sort of definition of being, the presence of the power to act or be acted upon in even the slightest degree.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is in reply to this that they say generation participates in the power of acting and of being acted upon, but that neither power is connected with being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: And is there not something in that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Yes, something to which we must reply that we still need to learn more clearly from them whether they agree that the soul knows and that being is known.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: They certainly assent to that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well then, do you say that knowing or being known is an active or passive condition, or both? Or that one is passive and the other active? Or that neither has any share at all in either of the two?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Clearly they would say that neither has any share in either; for otherwise they would be contradicting themselves.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I understand; this at least is true, that if to know is active, to be known must in turn be passive. Now being, since it is, according to this theory, known by the intelligence, in so far as it is known, is moved, since it is acted upon, which we say cannot be the case with that which is in a state of rest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But for heaven's sake, shall we let ourselves easily be persuaded that motion and life and soul and mind are really not present to absolute being, that it neither lives nor thinks, but awful and holy, devoid of mind, is fixed and immovable?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That would be a shocking admission to make, Stranger.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But shall we say that it has mind, but not life?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How can we?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But do we say that both of these exist in it, and yet go on to say that it does not possess them in a soul?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But how else can it possess them?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we say that it has mind and life and soul, but, although endowed with soul, is absolutely immovable?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: All those things seem to me absurd.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And it must be conceded that motion and that which is moved exist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the result is, Theaetetus, that if there is no motion, there is no mind in anyone about anything anywhere.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And on the other hand, if we admit that all things are in flux and motion, we shall remove mind itself from the number of existing things by this theory also.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you think that sameness of quality or nature or relations could ever come into existence without the state of rest?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What then? Without these can you see how mind could exist or come into existence anywhere?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet we certainly must contend by every argument against him who does away with knowledge or reason or mind and then makes any dogmatic assertion about anything.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then the philosopher, who pays the highest honor to these things, must necessarily, as it seems, because of them refuse to accept the theory of those who say the universe is at rest, whether as a unity or in many forms, and must also refuse utterly to listen to those who say that being is universal motion; he must quote the children's prayer,Nothing further seems to he known about this prayer. Stallbaum thought the reference was to a game in which the children said O(/SA A)KI/NHTA KAI\ KEKINHME/NA EI)/H, “may all unmoved things be moved.” “all things immovable and in motion,” and must say that being and the universe consist of both.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do we not, then, seem to have attained at last a pretty good definition of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But dear me, Theaetetus! I think we are now going to discover the difficulty of the inquiry about being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is this again? What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: My dear fellow, don't you see that we are now densely ignorant about it, but think that we are saying something worth while?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I think so, at any rate, and I do not at all understand what hidden error we have fallen into.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then watch more closely and see whether, if we make these admissions, we may not justly be asked the same questions we asked a while ago of those who said the universe was hot and cold.Cf. 242d above.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What questions? Remind me.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Certainly; and I will try to do this by questioning you, as we questioned them at the time. I hope we shall at the same time make a little progress.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Very well, then; you say that motion and rest are most directly opposed to each other, do you not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And yet you say that both and each of them equally exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in granting that they exist, do you mean to say that both and each are in motion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But do you mean that they are at rest, when you say that both exist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Being, then, you consider to be something else in the soul, a third in addition to these two, inasmuch as you think rest and motion are embraced by it; and since you comprehend and observe that they participate in existence, you therefore said that they are. Eh?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We really do seem to have a vague vision of being as some third thing, when we say that motion and rest are.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then being is not motion and rest in combination, but something else, different from them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Apparently.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: According to its own nature, then, being is neither at rest nor in motion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are about right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What is there left, then, to which a man can still turn his mind who wishes to establish within himself any clear conception of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What indeed?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: There is nothing left, I think, to which he can turn easily. For if a thing is not in motion, it must surely be at rest; and again, what is not at rest, must surely be in motion. But now we find that being has emerged outside of both these classes. Is that possible, then?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, nothing could be more impossible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then there is this further thing which we ought to remember.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That when we were asked to what the appellation of not-being should be applied, we were in the greatest perplexity. Do you remember?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course I do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, are we now in any less perplexity about being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It seems to me, stranger, that we are, if possible, in even greater.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: This point, then, let us put down definitely as one of complete perplexity. But since being and not-being participate equally in the perplexity, there is now at last some hope that as either of them emerges more dimly or more clearly, so also will the other emerge. If, however, we are able to see neither of them, we will at any rate push our discussion through between both of them at once as creditably as we can.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, explain how we come to be constantly calling this same thing by many names.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What, for instance? Please give an example.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We speak of man, you know, and give him many additional designations; we attribute to him colors and forms and sizes and vices and virtues, and in all these cases and countless others we say not only that he is man, but we say he is good and numberless other things. So in the same way every single thing which we supposed to be one, we treat as many and call by many names.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And it is in this way, I fancy, that we have provided a fine feast for youngsters and for old men whose learning has come to them late in life; for example, it is easy enough for anyone to grasp the notion that the many cannot possibly be one, nor the one many, and so, apparently, they take pleasure in saying that we must not call a man good, but must call the good good, and a man man. I fancy, Theaetetus, you often run across people who take such matters seriously; sometimes they are elderly men whose poverty of intellect makes them admire such quibbles, and who think this is a perfect mine of wisdom they have discovered.Those are here satirized who deny the possibillty of all except identical predication. Such were Antisthenes, Euthydemus, and Dionysodorus. The two last are probably those referred to as old men whose learning came late in life.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, to include in our discussion all those who have ever engaged in any talk whatsoever about being, let us address our present arguments to these men as well as to all those with whom we were conversing before, and let us employ the form of questions.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are the arguments?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we attribute neither being to rest and motion, nor any attribute to anything, but shall we in our discussions assume that they do not mingle and cannot participate in one another? Or shall we gather all things together, believing that they are capable of combining with one another? Or are some capable of it and others not? Which of these alternatives, Theaetetus, should we say is their choice?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I cannot answer these questions for them.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then why did you not answer each separately and see what the result was in each case?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: A good suggestion.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And let us, if you please, assume that they say first that nothing has any power to combine with anything else. Then motion and rest will have no share in being, will they?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, will either of them be, if it has no share in being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It will not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: See how by this admission everything is overturned at once, as it seems—the doctrine of those who advocate universal motion, that of the partisans of unity and rest, and that of the men who teach that all existing things are distributed into invariable and everlasting kinds. For all of these make use of being as an attribute. One party says that the universe “is” in motion, another that it “is” at rest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, all who teach that things combine at one time and separate at another, whether infinite elements combine in unity and are derived from unity or finite elements separate and then unite, regardless of whether they say that these changes take place successively or without interruption, would be talking nonsense in all these doctrines, if there is no intermingling.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, too, the very men who forbid us to call anything by another name because it participates in the effect produced by another, would be made most especially ridiculous by this doctrine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Because they are obliged in speaking of anything to use the expressions “to be,” “apart,” “from the rest,” “by itself,” and countless others; they are powerless to keep away from them or avoid working them into their discourse; and therefore there is no need of others to refute them, but, as the saying goes, their enemy and future opponent is of their own household whom they always carry about with them as they go, giving forth speech from within them, like the wonderful Eurycles.Eurycles was a ventriloquist and soothsayer of the fifth century, cf. Aristoph. Wasps 1019

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is a remarkably accurate illustration

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But what if we ascribe to all things the power of participation in one another?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Even I can dispose of that assumption.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Because motion itself would be wholly at rest, and rest in turn would itself be in motion, if these two could be joined with one another.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But surely this at least is most absolutely impossible, that motion be at rest and rest be in motion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then only the third possibility is left.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And certainly one of these three must be true; either all things will mingle with one another, or none will do so, or some will and others will not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And certainly the first two were found to be impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then everybody who wishes to answer correctly will adopt the remaining one of the three possibilities.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Precisely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now since some things will commingle and others will not, they are in much the same condition as the letters of the alphabet; for some of these do not fit each other, and others do.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the vowels, to a greater degree than the others, run through them all as a bond, so that without one of the vowels the other letters cannot be joined one to another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now does everybody know which letters can join with which others? Or does he who is to join them properly have need of art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: He has need of art.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The art of grammar.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And is not the same true in connection with high and low sounds? Is not he who has the art to know the sounds which mingle and those which do not, musical, and he who does not know unmusical?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall find similar conditions, then, in all the other arts and processes which are devoid of art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now since we have agreed that the classes or genera also commingle with one another, or do not commingle, in the same way, must not he possess some science and proceed by the processes of reason who is to show correctly which of the classes harmonize with which, and which reject one another, and also if he is to show whether there are some elements extending through all and holding them together so that they can mingle, and again, when they separate, whether there are other universal causes of separation?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly he needs science, and perhaps even the greatest of sciences.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, Theaetetus, what name shall we give to this science? Or, by Zeus, have we unwittingly stumbled upon the science that belongs to free men and perhaps found the philosopher while we were looking for the sophist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we not say that the division of things by classes and the avoidance of the belief that the same class is another, or another the same, belongs to the science of dialectic?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we shall.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then he who is able to do this has a clear perception of one form or idea extending entirely through many individuals each of which lies apart, and of many forms differing from one another but included in one greater form, and again of one form evolved by the union of many wholes, and of many forms entirely apart and separate. This is the knowledge and ability to distinguish by classes how individual things can or cannot be associated with one another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But you surely, I suppose, will not grant the art of dialectic to any but the man who pursues philosophy in purity and righteousness.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How could it be granted to anyone else?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is in some region like this that we shall always, both now and hereafter, discover the philosopher, if we look for him; he also is hard to see clearly, but the difficulty is not the same in his case and that of the sophist.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How do they differ?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The sophist runs away into the darkness of not-being, feeling his way in it by practice,By practice, i.e., by empirical knowledge as opposed to reason. and is hard to discern on account of the darkness of the place. Don't you think so?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It seems likely.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the philosopher, always devoting himself through reason to the idea of being, is also very difficult to see on account of the brilliant light of the place; for the eyes of the soul of the multitude are not strong enough to endure the sight of the divine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: This also seems no less true than what you said about the sophist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now we will make more accurate investigations about the philosopher hereafter, if we still care to do so; but as to the sophist, it is clear that we must not relax our efforts until we have a satisfactory view of him.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Since, therefore, we are agreed that some of the classes will mingle with one another, and others will not, and some will mingle with few and others with many, and that there is nothing to hinder some from mingling universally with all, let us next proceed with our discussion by investigating, not all the forms or ideas, lest we become confused among so many, but some only, selecting them from those that are considered the most important; let us first consider their several natures, then what their power of mingling with one another is, and so, if we cannot grasp being and not-being with perfect clearness, we shall at any rate not fail to reason fully about them, so far as the method of our present inquiry permits. Let us in this way see whether it is, after all, permitted us to say that not-being really is, although not being, and yet come off unscathed.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes; that is the proper thing for us to do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The most important, surely, of the classes or genera are those which we just mentioned; being itself and rest and motion.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, by far.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And further, two of them, we say, cannot mingle with each other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Decidedly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But being can mingle with both of them, for they both are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then these prove to be three.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Each of them is, then, other than the remaining two, but the same as itself.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But what do we mean by these words, “the same” and “other,” which we have just used? Are they two new classes, different from the other three, but always of necessity mingled with them, and must we conduct our inquiry on the assumption that there are five classes, not three, or are we unconsciously speaking of one of those three when we say “the same” or “other”?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But certainly motion and rest are neither other nor the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Whatever term we apply to rest and motion in common cannot be either of those two.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why not?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Because motion would be at rest and rest would be in motion; in respect of both, for whichever of the two became “other” would force the other to change its nature into that of its opposite, since it would participate in its opposite.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Both certainly partake of the same and the other.i.e., sameness and difference can he predicated of both.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must not say that motion, or rest either, is the same or other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But should we conceive of “being” and “the same” as one?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if “being” and “the same” have no difference of meaning, then when we go on and say that both rest and motion are, we shall be saying that they are both the same, since they are.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: But surely that is impossible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is impossible for being and the same to be one.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Pretty nearly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So we shall consider “the same” a fourth class in addition to the other three?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we call “the other” a fifth class? Or must we conceive of this and “being” as two names for one class?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: May be.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But I fancy you admit that among the entities some are always conceived as absolute, and some as relative.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And other is always relative to other, is it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It would not be so, if being and the other were not utterly different. If the other, like being, partook of both absolute and relative existence, there would be also among the others that exist another not in relation to any other; but as it is, we find that whatever is other is just what it is through compulsion of some other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: The facts are as you say.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must place the nature of “the other” as a fifth among the classes in which we select our examples.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall say that it permeates them all; for each of them is other than the rest, not by reason of its own nature, but because it partakes of the idea of the other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us now state our conclusions, taking up the five classes one at a time.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Take motion first; we say that it is entirely other than rest, do we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is not rest.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But it exists, by reason of its participation in being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it exists.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now motion again is other than the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You're about right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Therefore it is not the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, it is not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But yet we found it was the same, because all things partake of the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must admit that motion is the same and is not the same, and we must not be disturbed thereby; for when we say it is the same and not the same, we do not use the words alike. When we call it the same, we do so because it partakes of the same in relation to itself, and when we call it not the same, we do so on account of its participation in the other, by which it is separated from the same and becomes not that but other, so that it is correctly spoken of in turn as not the same.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then even if absolute motion partook in any way of rest, it would not be absurd to say it was at rest?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It would be perfectly right, if we are to admit that some of the classes will mingle with one another, and others will not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And surely we demonstrated that before we took up our present points; we proved that it was according to nature.See Plat. Theaet. 251e ff

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us recapitulate: Motion is other than the other, just as we found it to be other than the same and than rest. Is that true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Inevitably.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then it is in a sense not other and also other, according to our present reasoning.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now how about the next point? Shall we say next that motion is other than the three, but not other than the fourth,—that is, if we have agreed that the classes about which and within which we undertook to carry on our inquiry are five in number?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How can we say that? For we cannot admit that the number is less than was shown just now.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we may fearlessly persist in contending that motion is other than being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, most fearlessly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It is clear, then, that motion really is not, and also that it is, since it partakes of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is perfectly clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In relation to motion, then, not-being is. That is inevitable. And this extends to all the classes; for in all of them the nature of other so operates as to make each one other than being, and therefore not-being. So we may, from this point of view, rightly say of all of them alike that they are not; and again, since they partake of being, that they are and have being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I suppose so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so, in relation to each of the classes, being is many, and not-being is infinite in number.Being is many, for each and every thing in all the classes is; but not-being is infinite, for not only is it true that everything in each of the classes is not, but not-being extends also to all conceptions which do not and cannot have any reality.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it seems.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then being itself must also be said to be other than all other things.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it must.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we conclude that whatever the number of other things is, just that is the number of the things in relation to which being is not; for not being those things, it is itself one, and again, those other things are not unlimited in number.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is not far from the truth.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then we must not be disturbed by this either, since by their nature the classes have participation in one another. But if anyone refuses to accept our present results, let him reckon with our previous arguments and then proceed to reckon with the next step.i.e., if he will not accept our proof that being is not, etc., he must disprove our arguuents respecting the participation of idea in one another, and then proceed to draw his inference.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is very fair.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then here is a point to consider.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When we say not-being, we speak, I think, not of something that is the opposite of being, but only of something different.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For instance, when we speak of a thing as not great, do we seem to you to mean by the expression what is small any more than what is of middle size?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then when we are told that the negative signifies the opposite, we shall not admit it; we shall admit only that the particle “not”The two particles OU) and MH/ in Greek. indicates something different from the words to which it is prefixed, or rather from the things denoted by the words that follow the negative.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us consider another point and see if you agree with me.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: It seems to me that the nature of the other is all cut up into little bits, like knowledge.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Knowledge, like other, is one, but each separate part of it which applies to some particular subject has a name of its own; hence there are many arts, as they are called, and kinds of knowledge, or sciences.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the same is true, by their nature, of the parts of the other, though it also is one concept.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Perhaps; but let us discuss the matter and see how it comes about.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is there a part of the other which is opposed to the beautiful?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: There is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we say that this is nameless or that it has a name?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That it has one; for that which in each case we call not-beautiful is surely the other of the nature of the beautiful and of nothing else.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now, then, tell me something more.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Does it not result from this that the not-beautiful is a distinct part of some one class of being and also, again, opposed to some class of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, apparently, it follows that the not-beautiful is a contrast of being with being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Can we, then, in that case, say that the beautiful is more and the not-beautiful less a part of being?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Not at all.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence the not-great must be said to be no less truly than the great?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No less truly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And so we must recognize the same relation between the just and the not-just, in so far as neither has any more being than the other?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we shall, then, say the same of other things, since the nature of the other is proved to possess real being; and if it has being, we must necessarily ascribe being in no less degree to its parts also.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then, as it seems, the opposition of the nature of a part of the other, and of the nature of being, when they are opposed to one another, is no less truly existence than is being itself, if it is not wrong for me to say so, for it signifies not the opposite of being, but only the other of being, and nothing more.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is perfectly clear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then what shall we call this?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently this is precisely not-being, which we were looking for because of the sophist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And is this, as you were saying, as fully endowed with being as anything else, and shall we henceforth say with confidence that not-being has an assured existence and a nature of its own? Just as we found that the great was great and the beautiful was beautiful, the not-great was not-great and the not-beautiful was not-beautiful, shall we in the same way say that not-being was and is not-being, to be counted as one class among the many classes of being? Or have we, Theaetetus, any remaining distrust about the matter?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: None whatever.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you observe, then, that we have gone farther in our distrust of Parmenides than the limit set by his prohibition?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We have proceeded farther in our investigation and have shown him more than that which he forbade us to examine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is what he says.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we have not only pointed out that things which are not exist, but we have even shown what the form or class of not-being is; for we have pointed out that the nature of the other exists and is distributed in small bits throughout all existing things in their relations to one another, and we have ventured to say that each part of the other which is contrasted with being, really is exactly not-being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: And certainly, Stranger, I think that what we have said is perfectly true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let not anyone assert that we declare that not-being is the opposite of being, and hence are so rash as to say that not-being exists. For we long ago gave up speaking of any opposite of being, whether it exists or not and is capable or totally incapable of definition. But as for our present definition of not-being, a man must either refute us and show that we are wrong, or, so long as he cannot do that, he too must say, as we do, that the classes mingle with one another, and being and the other permeate all things, including each other, and the other, since it participates in being, is, by reason of this participation, yet is not that in which it participates, but other, and since it is other than being, must inevitably be not-being. But being, in turn, participates in the other and is therefore other than the rest of the classes, and since it is other than all of them, it is not each one of them or all the rest, but only itself; there is therefore no doubt that there are thousands and thousands of things which being is not, and just so all other things, both individually and collectively, in many relations are, and in many are not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if any man has doubts about these oppositions, he must make investigations and advance better doctrines than these of ours; or if he finds pleasure in dragging words about and applying them to different things at different times, with the notion that he has invented something difficult to explain, our present argument asserts that he has taken up seriously matters which are not worth serious attention; for this process is neither clever nor difficult, whereas here now is something both difficult and beautiful.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What I have spoken of before—the ability to let those quibbles go as of no account and to follow and refute in detail the arguments of a man who says that other is in a sense the same, or that the same is other, and to do this from that point of view and with regard for those relations which he presupposes for either of these conditions. But to show that in some sort of fashion the same is the other, and the other the same, and the great small, and the like unlike, and to take pleasure in thus always bringing forward opposites in the argument,—all that is no true refutation, but is plainly the newborn offspring of some brain that has just begun to lay hold upon the problem of realities.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For certainly, my friend, the attempt to separate everything from everything else is not only not in good taste but also shows that a man is utterly uncultivated and unphilosophical.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The complete separation of each thing from all is the utterly final obliteration of all discourse. For our power of discourse is derived from the interweaving of the classes or ideas with one another.The denial, that is to say, of all the interrelations of ideas leads to purely negative results. Examples of this are the exclusive antithesis of being and not-being and the mutual exclusion of rest and motion. The difficulty is solved at once when we recognize that positive and negative are necessarily interwoven in the nature of things, that the negative has only a relative existence and is not the opposite of the positive, but only different from it.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Observe, then, that we have now been just in time in carrying our point against the supporters of such doctrine, and in forcing them to admit that one thing mingles with another.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What was our object?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Our object was to establish discourse as one of our classes of being. For if we were deprived of this, we should be deprived of philosophy, which would be the greatest calamity; moreover, we must at the present moment come to an agreement about the nature of discourse, and if we were robbed of it by its absolute non-existence, we could no longer discourse; and we should be robbed of it if we agreed that there is no mixture of anything with anything.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is true enough; but I do not understand why we must come to an agreement about discourse just now.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Perhaps the easiest way for you to understand is by following this line of argument.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What line?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We found that not-being was one of the classes of being, permeating all being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So the next thing is to inquire whether it mingles with opinion and speech.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: If it does not mingle with them, the necessary result is that all things are true, but if it does, then false opinion and false discourse come into being; for to think or say what is not—that is, I suppose, falsehood arising in mind or in words.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: So it is.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But if falsehood exists, deceit exists.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if deceit exists, all things must be henceforth full of images and likenesses and fancies.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we said that the sophist had taken refuge in this region and had absolutely denied the existence of falsehood: for he said that not-being could be neither conceived nor uttered, since not-being did not in any way participate in being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, so it was.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now not-being has been found to partake of being, and so, perhaps, he would no longer keep up the fight in this direction; but he might say that some ideas partake of not-being and some do not, and that speech and opinion are among those which do not; and he would therefore again contend that the image-making and fantastic art, in which we placed him, has absolutely no existence, since opinion and speech have no participation in not-being; for falsehood cannot possibly exist unless such participation takes place. For this reason we must first inquire into the nature of speech and opinion and fancy,The English word “fancy,” though etymologically identical with the Greek FANTASI/A, has lost the close connection with “seeming” (FAI/NESQAI) which the Greek retains. The Greek word is therefore more comprehensive than the English, denoting that which appears to be, whether as the result of imagination or of sensation. Cf. 235 D ff. in order that when they are made clear we may perceive that they participate in not-being, and when we have perceived that, may prove the existence of falsehood, and after proving that, may imprison the sophist therein, if he can be held on that charge, and if not, may set him free and seek him in another class.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: It certainly seems, Stranger, that what you said at first about the sophist—that he was a hard kind of creature to catch—is true; for he seems to have no end of defences,Perhaps a sort of pun is intended, for PRO/BLHMA was already beginning to have the meaning of “problem.” and when he throws one of them up, his opponent has first to fight through it before he can reach the man himself; for now, you see, we have barely passed through the non-existence of being, which was his first prepared line of defence, when we find another line ready; and so we must prove that falsehood exists in relation to opinion and to speech; and after this, perhaps, there will be another line, and still another after that; and it seems no end will ever appear.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: No one should be discouraged, Theaetetus, who can make constant progress, even though it be slow. For if a man is discouraged under these conditions, what would he do under others—if he did not get ahead at all or were even pressed back? It would be a long time, as the saying is, before such a man would ever take a city. But now, my friend, since we have passed the line you speak of, the main defences would surely be in our hands, and the rest will now be smaller and easier to take.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: First, then, let us take up speech and opinion, as I said just now, in order to come to a clearer understanding whether not-being touches them, or they are both entirely true, and neither is ever false.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us now investigate names, just a we spoke a while ago about ideas and letters; for in that direction the object of our present search is coming in sight.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do we need to understand about names?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Whether they all unite with one another, or none of them, or some will and some will not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Evidently the last; some will and some will not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: This, perhaps, is what you mean, that those which are spoken in order and mean something do unite, but those that mean nothing in their sequence do not unite.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so, and what do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: What I supposed you had in mind when you assented; for we have two kinds of vocal indications of being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How so?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One called nouns, the other verbs.The science of language, in all its branches, was young in the time of Plato. Words of general meaning were necessarily used in a technical sense. So here O)/NOMA and R(H=MA are used as parts of grammatical terminology in the sense of “verb” and “noun,” though Plato elsewhere employs them with their ordinary meanings. Similarly the distinction between vowels and consonants (Plat. Theaet. 203; cf. Plat. Soph. 253) was at least relatively new, as was that between the active and the passive voice. How important Plato's part was in the development of linguistic study can no longer be accurately determined.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Define each of them.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The indication which relates to action we may call a verb.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the vocal sign applied to those who perform the actions in question we call a noun.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Exactly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Hence discourse is never composed of nouns alone spoken in succession, nor of verbs spoken without nouns.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I do not understand that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I see; you evidently had something else in mind when you assented just now; for what I wished to say was just this, that verbs and nouns do not make discourse if spoken successively in this way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: In what way?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For instance, “walks,” “runs,” “sleeps” and the other verbs which denote actions, even if you utter all there are of them in succession, do not make discourse for all that.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, of course not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again, when “lion,” “stag,” “horse,” and all other names of those who perform these actions are uttered, such a succession of words does not yet make discourse; for in neither case do the words uttered indicate action or inaction or existence of anything that exists or does not exist, until the verbs are mingled with the nouns; then the words fit, and their first combination is a sentence, about the first and shortest form of discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean by that?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When one says “a man learns,” you agree that this is the least and first of sentences, do you not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: For when he says that, he makes a statement about that which is or is becoming or has become or is to be; he does not merely give names, but he reaches a conclusion by combining verbs with nouns. That is why we said that he discourses and does not merely give names, and therefore we gave to this combination the name of discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That was right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: So, then, just as of things some fit each other and some do not, so too some vocal signs do not fit, but some of them do fit and form discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now there is another little point.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: A sentence, if it is to be a sentence, must have a subject; without a subject it is impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And it must also be of some quality, must it not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now let us pay attention to each other.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, at any rate we ought to do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now, then, I will speak a sentence to you in which a action and the result of action are combined by means of a noun and a verb, and whatever the subject of the sentence is do you tell me.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I will, to the best of my ability.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: “Theaetetus sits.” It isn't a long sentence, is it?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No, it is fairly short.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now it is for you to say what it is about and what its subject is.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Clearly it is about me, and I am its subject.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about this sentence?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What one?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: “Theaetetus, with whom I am now talking, flies.”

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Every one would agree that this also is about me and I am its subject.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we agree that every sentence must have some quality.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now what quality shall be ascribed to each of these sentences?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: One is false, I suppose, the other true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The true one states facts as they are about you.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the false one states things that are other than the facts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In other words, it speaks of things that are not as if they were.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, that is pretty much what it does.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And states with reference to you that things are which are other than things which actually are; for we said, you know, that in respect to everything there are many things that are and many that are not.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: To be sure.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now the second of my sentences about you is in the first place by sheer necessity one of the shortest which conform to our definition of sentence.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: At any rate we just now agreed on that point.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And secondly it has a subject.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if you are not the subject, there is none.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And if there is no subject, it would not be a sentence at all; for we showed that a sentence without a subject is impossible.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now when things are said about you, but things other are said as the same and things that are not as things that are, it appears that when such a combination is formed of verbs and nouns we have really and truly false discourse.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, very truly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Is it, then, not already plain that the three classes, thought, opinion, and fancy, all arise in our minds as both false and true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How is it plain?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You will understand more easily if you first grap their natures and the several differences between them.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Give me an opportunity.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, then, thought and speech are the same; only the former, which is a silent inner conversation of the soul with itself, has been given the special name of thought. Is not that true?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But the stream that flows from the soul in vocal utterance through the mouth has the name of speech?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in speech we know there is just—

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Affirmation and negation

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we know that.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now when this arises in the soul silently by way of thought, can you give it any other name than opinion?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly not.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And when such a condition is brought about in anyone, not independently, but through sensation, can it properly be called anything but seeming, or fancy?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then since speech, as we found, is true and false, and we saw that thought is conversation of the soul with itself, and opinion is the final result of thought, and what we mean when we say “it seems” is a mixture of sensation and opinion, it is inevitable that, since these are all akin to speech, some of them must sometimes be false.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do you see, then, that false opinion and false discourse were found sooner than we expected when we feared a few moments ago that in looking for them we were undertaking an endless task?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, I see.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us not be discouraged about the rest of our search, either; for now that these points are settled, we have only to revert to our previous divisions into classes.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What divisions?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We made two classes of image-making, the likeness-making and the fantastic.See Plat. Theaet. 235d ff

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we said that we did not know to which of the two the sophist should be assigned.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in the midst of our perplexity about that, we were overwhelmed by a still greater dizziness when the doctrine appeared which challenges everybody and asserts that neither likeness nor image nor appearance exists at all, because falsehood never exists anywhere in any way.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now, since the existence of false speech and false opinion has been proved, it is possible for imitations of realities to exist and for an art of deception to arise from this condition of mind.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, it is possible.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And we decided some time ago that the sophist was in one of those two divisions of the image-making class.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us try again; let us divide in two the class we have taken up for discussion, and proceed always by way of the right-hand part of the thing divided, clinging close to the company to which the sophist belongs, until, having stripped him of all common properties and left him only his own peculiar nature, we shall show him plainly first to ourselves and secondly to those who are most closely akin to the dialectic method.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We began by making two divisions of art, the productive and the acquisitive, did we not?See Plat. Theaet. 219

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And the sophist showed himself to us in the arts of hunting, contests, commerce, and the like, which were subdivisions of acquisitive art?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But now, since imitative art has taken him over, it is clear that our first step must be the division of productive art into two parts; for imitative art is a kind of production—of images, however, we say, not of real things in each case. Do you agree?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us first assume two parts of productive art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The divine and the human.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I don't yet understand.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We said, if we remember the beginning of our conversation, that every power is productive which causes things to come into being which did not exist before.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, we remember.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: There are all the animals, and all the plants that grow out of the earth from seeds and roots, and all the lifeless substances, fusible and infusible, that are formed within the earth. Shall we say that they came into being, not having been before, in any other way than through God's workmanship? Or, accepting the commonly expressed belief—

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What belief?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: That nature brings them forth from some self-acting cause, without creative intelligence. Or shall we say that they are created by reason and by divine knowledge that comes from God?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I, perhaps because I am young, often change from one opinion to the other; but now, looking at you and considering that you think they are created by God, I also adopt that view.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well said, Theaetetus; and if I thought you were one of those who would think differently by and by, I should try now, by argument and urgent persuasion, to make you agree with my opinion; but since I understand your nature and see that it of itself inclines, without any words of mine, towards that to which you say you are at present attracted, I will let that go; for it would be a waste of time. But I will assume that things which people call natural are made by divine art, and things put together by man out of those as materials are made by human art, and that there are accordingly two kinds of art, the one human and the other divine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Now that there are two, divide each of them again.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: You divided all productive art widthwise, as it were, before; now divide it lengthwise.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Assume that it is done.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: In that way we now get four parts in all; two belong to us and are human, and two belong to the gods and are divine.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And again, when the section is made the other way, one part of each half has to do with the making of real things, and the two remaining parts may very well be called image-making; and so productive art is again divided into two parts.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Tell me again how each part is distinguished.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We know that we and all the other animals, and fire, water, and their kindred elements, out of which natural objects are formed, are one and all the very offspring and creations of God, do we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And corresponding to each and all of these there are images, not the things themselves, which are also made by superhuman skill.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The appearances in dreams, and those that arise by day and are said to be spontaneous—a shadow when a dark object interrupts the firelight, or when twofold light, from the objects themselves and from outside, meets on smooth and bright surfaces and causes upon our senses an effect the reverse of our ordinary sight, thus producing an image.This was the current explanation of reflection. Mirrors and smooth objects were supposed to contain a luminous principle which met on the smooth surface with the light coming from the object reflected. So in the act of vision the fire within the eye united with the external fire (Plat. Tim. 46a). The words TH=S E)/MPROSQEN . . . E)NANTI/AN AI)/SQHSIN refer to the transposition of right and left in the reflection (cf. Plat. Theaet. 193c).

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, these are two works of divine creation, the thing itself and the corresponding image in each case.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And how about our own art? Shall we not say that we make a house by the art of building, and by the art of painting make another house, a sort of man-made dream produced for those who are awake?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And in the same way, we say, all the other works of our creative activity also are twofold and go in pairs—the thing itself, produced by the art that creates real things, and the image, produced by the image-making art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: I understand better now; and I agree that there are two kinds of production, each of them twofold—the divine and the human by one method of bisection, and by the other real things and the product that consists of a sort of likenesses.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We must remember that there were to be two parts of the image-making class, the likeness-making and the fantastic, if we should find that falsehood really existed and was in the class of real being.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, there were.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But we found that falsehood does exist, and therefore we shall now, without any doubts, number the kinds of image-making art as two, shall we not?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, again bisect the fantastic art.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: One kind is that produced by instruments, the other that in which the producer of the appearance offers himself as the instrument.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: When anyone, by employing his own person as his instrument, makes his own figure or voice seem similar to yours, that kind of fantastic art is called mimetic.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Let us, then, classify this part under the name of mimetic art; but as for all the rest, let us be so self-indulgent as to let it go and leave it for someone else to unify and name appropriately.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very well, let us adopt that classification and let the other part go.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But it is surely worth while to consider, Theaetetus, that the mimetic art also has two parts; and I will tell you why.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Please do.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Some who imitate do so with knowledge of that which they imitate, and others without such knowledge. And yet what division can we imagine more complete than that which separates knowledge and ignorance?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: None.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The example I just gave was of imitation by those who know, was it not? For a man who imitates you would know you and your figure.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Of course.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: But what of the figure of justice and, in a word, of virtue in general? Are there not many who have no knowledge of it, but only a sort of opinion, and who try with the greatest eagerness to make this which they themselves think is virtue seem to exist within them, by imitating it in acts and words to the best of their ability?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, there are very many such people.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Do all of them, then, fail in the attempt to seem to be just when they are not so at all? Or is quite the opposite the case?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Quite the opposite.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then I think we must say that such an imitator is quite distinct from the other, the one who does not know from the one who knows.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Where, then, can the fitting name for each of the two be found? Clearly it is not an easy task, because there was, it seems, among the earlier thinkers a long established and careless indolence in respect to the division of classes or genera into forms or species, so that nobody even tried to make such divisions; therefore there cannot be a great abundance of names. However, even though the innovation in language be a trifle bold, let us, for the sake of making a distinction, call the imitation which is based on opinion, oplnion-imitation, and that which is founded on knowledge, a sort of scientific imitation.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: We mat therefore apply ourselves to the former, for we found that the sophist was among those who imitate but was not among those who know.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Very true.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then let us examine the opinion-imitator as if he were a piece of iron, and see whether he is sound or there is still some seam in him.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Let us do so.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Well, there is a very marked seam. For some of these imitators are simple-minded and think they know that about which they have only opinion, but the other kind because of their experience in the rough and tumble of arguments, strongly suspect and fear that they are ignorant of the things which they pretend before the public to know.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Certainly the two classes you mention both exist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Then shall we call one the simple imitator and the other the dissembling imitator?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is reaonable, at any rate.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And shall we say that the latter forms one class or two again?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: That is your affair.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: I am considering, and I think I can see two classes I see one who can dissemble in long speeches in public before a multitude, and the other who does it in private in short speeches and forces the person who converses with him to contradict himself.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: You are quite right.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what name shall we give to him who makes the longer speeches? Statesman or popular orator?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Popular orator.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: And what shall we call the other? Philosopher or sophist?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: We cannot very well call him philosopher, since by our hypothesis he is ignorant; but since he is all imitator of the philosopher, he will evidently have a name derived from his, and I think I am sure at last that we must truly call him the absolutely real and actual sophist.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: Shall we then bind up his name as we did before, winding it up from the end to the beginning?

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: By all means.

sp.speaker: Stranger
sp.p: The imitative kind of the dissembling part of the art of opinion which is part of the art of contradiction and belongs to the fantastic class of the image-making art, and is not divine, but human, and has been defined in arguments as the juggling part of productive activity—he who says that the true sophist is of this descent and blood will, in my opinion, speak the exact truth.

sp.speaker: Theaetetus
sp.p: Yes, he certainly will.
